question.title: How do determine if an object is locked (synchronized) so not to block in Java?

node.contents: I have a process A that contains a table in memory with a set of records (recordA, recordB, etc...)

astNode.text: I have a process A that contains a table in memory with a set of records (recordA, recordB, etc...)

node.contents: Now, this process can launch many threads that affect the records, and sometimes we can have 2 threads trying to access the same record - this situation must be denied. Specifically if a record is LOCKED by one thread I want the other thread to abort (I do not want to BLOCK or WAIT).

astNode.text: Now, this process can launch many threads that affect the records, and sometimes we can have 2 threads trying to access the same record - this situation must be denied. Specifically if a record is LOCKED by one thread I want the other thread to abort (I do not want to BLOCK or WAIT).

node.contents: Currently I do something like this:

astNode.text: Currently I do something like this:

node.contents: But this is causing me problems ... because while Process1 is performing the operation, if Process2 comes in it blocks/waits on the synchronized statement and when Process1 is finished it performs the operation. Instead I want something like this:

astNode.text: But this is causing me problems ... because while Process1 is performing the operation, if Process2 comes in it blocks/waits on the synchronized statement and when Process1 is finished it performs the operation. Instead I want something like this:

elements.contents: if (record is locked) return; synchronized(record) { performOperation(record); }

units.rawText: if (record is locked) return; synchronized(record) { performOperation(record); }

node.contents: Any clues on how this can be accomplished? Any help would be much appreciated. Thanks,

astNode.text: Any clues on how this can be accomplished? Any help would be much appreciated. Thanks,

node.contents: While the Lock answers are very good, I thought I'd post an alternative using a different data structure. Essentially, your various threads want to know which records are locked and which aren't. One way to do this is to keep track of the locked records and make sure that data structure has the right atomic operations for adding records to the locked set.

astNode.text: While the Lock answers are very good, I thought I'd post an alternative using a different data structure. Essentially, your various threads want to know which records are locked and which aren't. One way to do this is to keep track of the locked records and make sure that data structure has the right atomic operations for adding records to the locked set.

node.contents: I will use CopyOnWriteArrayList as an example because it's less "magic" for illustration. CopyOnWriteArraySet is a more appropriate structure. If you have lots and lots of records locked at the same time on average then there may be performance implications with these implementations. A properly synchronized HashSet would work too and locks are brief.

astNode.text: I will use CopyOnWriteArrayList as an example because it's less "magic" for illustration. CopyOnWriteArraySet is a more appropriate structure. If you have lots and lots of records locked at the same time on average then there may be performance implications with these implementations. A properly synchronized HashSet would work too and locks are brief.

node.contents: Basically, usage code would look like this:

astNode.text: Basically, usage code would look like this:

elements.contents: CopyOnWriteArrayList<Record> lockedRecords = .... ... if (!lockedRecords.addIfAbsent(record)) return; // didn't get the lock, record is already locked try { // Do the record stuff } finally { lockedRecords.remove(record); }

comments.text: // didn't get the lock, record is already locked try { // Do the record stuff } finally { lockedRecords.remove(record); }

units.rawText: CopyOnWriteArrayList<Record> lockedRecords = .... ... if (!lockedRecords.addIfAbsent(record)) return; // didn't get the lock, record is already locked try { // Do the record stuff } finally { lockedRecords.remove(record); }

node.contents: It keeps you from having to manage a lock per record and provides a single place should clearing all locks be necessary for some reason. On the other hand, if you ever have more than a handful of records then a real HashSet with synchronization may do better since the add/remove look-ups will be O(1) instead of linear.

astNode.text: It keeps you from having to manage a lock per record and provides a single place should clearing all locks be necessary for some reason. On the other hand, if you ever have more than a handful of records then a real HashSet with synchronization may do better since the add/remove look-ups will be O(1) instead of linear.

node.contents: Just a different way of looking at things. Just depends on what your actual threading requirements are. Personally, I would use a Collections.synchronizedSet( new HashSet() ) because it will be really fast... the only implication is that threads may yield when they otherwise wouldn't have.

astNode.text: Just a different way of looking at things. Just depends on what your actual threading requirements are. Personally, I would use a Collections.synchronizedSet( new HashSet() ) because it will be really fast... the only implication is that threads may yield when they otherwise wouldn't have.

node.contents: I found this, we can use Thread.holdsLock(Object obj) to check if that object is locked

astNode.text: I found this, we can use Thread.holdsLock(Object obj) to check if that object is locked

node.contents: http://javarevisited.blogspot.in/2010/10/how-to-check-if-thread-has-lock-on.html

astNode.text: http://javarevisited.blogspot.in/2010/10/how-to-check-if-thread-has-lock-on.html

node.contents: Take a look at the Lock objects introduced in the Java 5 concurrency packages.

astNode.text: Take a look at the Lock objects introduced in the Java 5 concurrency packages.

elements.contents: Lock lock = new ReentrantLock() if (lock.tryLock()) { try { // do stuff using the lock... } finally { lock.unlock(); } } ...

comments.text: // do stuff using the lock... } finally { lock.unlock(); } } ...

node.contents: The ReentrantLock object is essentially doing the same thing as the traditional synchronized mechanism, but with more functionality.

astNode.text: The ReentrantLock object is essentially doing the same thing as the traditional synchronized mechanism, but with more functionality.

node.contents: EDIT: As Jon has noted, the isLocked() method tells you at that instant, and thereafter that information is out of date. The tryLock() method will give more reliable operation (note you can use this with a timeout as well)

astNode.text: EDIT: As Jon has noted, the isLocked() method tells you at that instant, and thereafter that information is out of date. The tryLock() method will give more reliable operation (note you can use this with a timeout as well)

node.contents: EDIT #2: Example now includes tryLock()/unlock() for clarity.

astNode.text: EDIT #2: Example now includes tryLock()/unlock() for clarity.

node.contents: In addition to this thread being old and having a good answer, this answer here is not good. If you really want to lock using a monitor, you can use Thread.holdsLock(object).

astNode.text: In addition to this thread being old and having a good answer, this answer here is not good. If you really want to lock using a monitor, you can use Thread.holdsLock(object).

node.contents: Whilst the above approach using a Lock object is the best way to do it, if you have to be able to check for locking using a monitor, it can be done. However, it does come with a health warning as the technique isn't portable to non Oracle Java VMs and it may break in future VM versions as it isn't a supported public API.

astNode.text: Whilst the above approach using a Lock object is the best way to do it, if you have to be able to check for locking using a monitor, it can be done. However, it does come with a health warning as the technique isn't portable to non Oracle Java VMs and it may break in future VM versions as it isn't a supported public API.

node.contents: Here is how to do it:

astNode.text: Here is how to do it:

elements.contents: private static sun.misc.Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field field = sun.misc.Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) field.get(null); } catch (Exception e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } } public void doSomething() { Object record = new Object(); sun.misc.Unsafe unsafe = getUnsafe(); if (unsafe.tryMonitorEnter(record)) { try { // record is locked - perform operations on it } finally { unsafe.monitorExit(record); } } else { // could not lock record } }

comments.text: // record is locked - perform operations on it } finally { unsafe.monitorExit(record); } } else { // could not lock record } }

node.contents: My advice would be to use this approach only if you cannot refactor your code to use java.util.concurrent Lock objects for this and if you are running on an Oracle VM.

astNode.text: My advice would be to use this approach only if you cannot refactor your code to use java.util.concurrent Lock objects for this and if you are running on an Oracle VM.

node.contents: Yes. That's a good point. I took the example code literally, whereas the above is definitely a more robust implementation

astNode.text: Yes. That's a good point. I took the example code literally, whereas the above is definitely a more robust implementation

node.contents: But how do I use a lock per record? Currently the records are stored in a HashTable of records ... so I need a matching Hashtable of Locks? I am trying to ensure I have the most possible concurrency, so if a process wants to access recordC that should be fine (if only recordB is locked) - I use a global LOCK then it is essentially the same as locking the entire hashtable. ... that make any sense?

astNode.text: But how do I use a lock per record? Currently the records are stored in a HashTable of records ... so I need a matching Hashtable of Locks? I am trying to ensure I have the most possible concurrency, so if a process wants to access recordC that should be fine (if only recordB is locked) - I use a global LOCK then it is essentially the same as locking the entire hashtable. ... that make any sense?

node.contents: @Shaitan00: The easiest way would be to have a lock within the record. Basically you want one lock associated with each record - so put it in the object.

astNode.text: @Shaitan00: The easiest way would be to have a lock within the record. Basically you want one lock associated with each record - so put it in the object.

node.contents: Obviously :) I assume that I do not need to manage unlocking? Meaning when it exits the {} of the .tryLock() it will automatically & immediatly be unlocked correct?

astNode.text: Obviously :) I assume that I do not need to manage unlocking? Meaning when it exits the {} of the .tryLock() it will automatically & immediatly be unlocked correct?

node.contents: You do need to manage unlocking. See the tutorial I referenced in my answer and the unlock() method in the finally{} block

astNode.text: You do need to manage unlocking. See the tutorial I referenced in my answer and the unlock() method in the finally{} block

node.contents: From the sample provided by Jon there is no try/catch/finally - and from reading the tryLock() the lock is aquired automatically if it returns true. So ... how do I manage the unlocking? if (lock.tryLock() { do the work lock.unlock(); } else { throw exception locked }

astNode.text: From the sample provided by Jon there is no try/catch/finally - and from reading the tryLock() the lock is aquired automatically if it returns true. So ... how do I manage the unlocking? if (lock.tryLock() { do the work lock.unlock(); } else { throw exception locked }

node.contents: @Shaitan00: If you follow the link there's more example code. You put the try/finally inside the `if (lock.tryLock())` basically.

astNode.text: @Shaitan00: If you follow the link there's more example code. You put the try/finally inside the `if (lock.tryLock())` basically.

node.contents: One thing to note is that the instant you receive such information, it's stale. In other words, you could be told that no-one has the lock, but then when you try to acquire it, you block because another thread took out the lock between the check and you trying to acquire it.

astNode.text: One thing to note is that the instant you receive such information, it's stale. In other words, you could be told that no-one has the lock, but then when you try to acquire it, you block because another thread took out the lock between the check and you trying to acquire it.

node.contents: Brian is right to point at Lock, but I think what you really want is its tryLock method:

astNode.text: Brian is right to point at Lock, but I think what you really want is its tryLock method:

elements.contents: if (lock.tryLock()) { // Got the lock try { // Process record } finally { // Make sure to unlock so that we don't cause a deadlock lock.unlock(); } } else { // Someone else had the lock, abort }

comments.text: // Got the lock try { // Process record } finally { // Make sure to unlock so that we don't cause a deadlock lock.unlock(); } } else { // Someone else had the lock, abort }

node.contents: You can also call tryLock with an amount of time to wait - so you could try to acquire it for a tenth of a second, then abort if you can't get it (for example).

astNode.text: You can also call tryLock with an amount of time to wait - so you could try to acquire it for a tenth of a second, then abort if you can't get it (for example).

node.contents: (I think it's a pity that the Java API doesn't - as far as I'm aware - provide the same functionality for the "built-in" locking, as the Monitor class does in .NET. Then again, there are plenty of other things I dislike in both platforms when it comes to threading - every object potentially having a monitor, for example!)

astNode.text: (I think it's a pity that the Java API doesn't - as far as I'm aware - provide the same functionality for the "built-in" locking, as the Monitor class does in .NET. Then again, there are plenty of other things I dislike in both platforms when it comes to threading - every object potentially having a monitor, for example!)
